questions.text: The ischial spine corresponds to which level?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B -

References:

  • ↳ The ischial spine refers to the sharp bony prominence which protrudes from the posterior margin of the ischium. It separates the greater sciatic notch above from the lesser sciatic notch below.
  • ↳ Despite commonly being referenced in relation to the S3-S5 vertebral level in some anatomical texts, in certain contexts or specific anatomical references, it may be aligned or associated with the tip of the coccyx.
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of Option B
  • ↳ Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of Option B
  • ↳ Option A, C and D:

questions.text: Which of the following hormones are secreted from each layer of the structure marked in the image given below? a. Glomerulosa- Aldosterone b. Fasciculata- Glucocorticoids c. Reticulata- Androgens d. Medulla- Epinephrine

options.label: D
options.text: a, b c & d are correct

questions.correct_answer: D. a, b c & d are correct
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - a, b c & d are correct:

Hormones of adrenal gland

Layers (weight)

Hormone production

 

 

 

 

 

Cortex (72%)

Z. Glomerulosa (15%)
  • Mineralocorticoids:
    • Aldosterone (main)
    • Deoxycorticosterone

Z. Fasciculata (50%)
  • Glucocorticoids (main)
    • Cortisol
    • corticosterone
  • Sex steroids

Z. Reticularis (7%)
  • Sex steroid (main)
    • Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)
    • Androstenedione
  • Glucocorticoids

Medulla (28%)

  • Epinephrine (90%)
  • Nor-epinephrine (10%)

questions.text: Which of the following features does not distinguish between necrosis and apoptosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Feature

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Cell Size

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Nucleus

Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, karyolysis

Fragmentation into nucleosome-size fragments

Plasma Membrane

Disrupted

Intact; altered structure, particularly lipid orientation

Cellular Contents

Enzymatic breakdown; potential leakage

Intact; released within apoptotic bodies

Adjacent Inflammation

Common

Absent

Physiological or Pathological Role

Typically pathological (resulting from irreversible cell injury)

Primarily physiological, serving to eliminate unwanted cells; may become pathological after certain types of cellular damage, notably DNA injury

questions.text: ER positivity is used as which of the following in the context of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Correct option B - Prognostic marker:

ER +ve status

ER -ve status
  • Prognosis is good.
  • Hormone therapy including tamoxifen is more beneficial.
  • Response to treatment is better.
  • Prognosis is poor.
  • Hormone therapy is not very beneficial (but used) as compared to ER +ve patients.
  • Response to treatment is not good.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a fracture of the intracapsular neck of the femur. What is the standard management done in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Details
Common in Elderly, especially osteoporotic bones
Type of fracture Intracapsular (femoral neck, within joint capsule)
Risk Disruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis
Goal of treatment Restore mobility, minimize complications of immobility
Preferred treatment (elderly) Hemiarthroplasty – replacement of femoral head
Preferred treatment (young) Internal fixation with cannulated screws or DHS

questions.text: A patient with invasive ductal carcinoma in situ presents with ulceration on skin and inflammatory signs. Nipple retraction was also present. What is the stage?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Stage 3b:

When T is

When N is

When M is

  • T4a- Extension to chest wall Ribs + intercostal muscles + Serratus anterior
  • T4b- The skin changes are involved (All the changes should be confined to the same breast)
    • Ulceration
    • Edema including Peau-D' orange
    • Satellite nodules
  • T4c- T4a + T4b
  • T4d- Inflammatory breast cancer
  • N0- No regional lymph node involvement
  • N1- Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary lymph node level I and II (mobile)
  • N2- Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary lymph node level I and II (fixed/matted)

 
  • M0- No clinical or radiological distant metastasis.

questions.text: Consider the following assertion and reason regarding Plasmodium falciparum infection: Assertion: P. falciparum doesn’t show schizont stage in peripheral blood. Reason: They get sequestered in small capillaries due to attachment to membranes. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is correct, but the reason is incorrect.

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is incorrect, but the reason is correct.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.:

Red blood cell

↓

Infected by P.falciparum (infects brain)

↓

P.falciparum starts making knobs - PF-Erythrocyte Membrane Protein

↓

These knobs will bind to ICAM present in endothelial cells

↓

The cell will get adhered - Cytoadherence

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in the primary survey of trauma?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - NCCT h

Primary survey

Adjuncts of primary survey
  • Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection
  • Breathing includes ventilation and oxygenation
  • Circulation with hemorrhage control
  • Disability (brief neurological examination)
  • Exposure with environmental control
  • Oxygen
  • Pulse oximetry
  • BP monitoring
  • ECG monitoring
  • NG tube, urinary catheter insertion
  • Ventilation rate
  • ABG levels
  • X-ray- Chest and pelvis
  • FAST

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Phacolytic glau

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type Subtypes Main Cause Key Clinical Feature
Arterial Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) Embolism (carotid or cardiac) Sudden, complete monocular blindness
  Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO) Embolism to a branch retinal artery Sudden, sectoral visual field loss
Venous Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) Hypertension, glaucoma, hyperviscosity Gradual or sudden blurring, "blood and thunder" fundus
  Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Sectoral hemorrhages, partial visual blurring
Occlusion Type Pathogenesis
Artery Embolic or thrombotic occlusion → retinal ischemia → inner retinal layer damage
Vein Venous stasis + increased backpressure → hemorrhage, macular edema, ischemia
Condition Fundus Appearance
CRAO Pale retina, cherry-red spot at macula
BRAO Localized pale retina corresponding to affected artery
CRVO Diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous veins, optic disc edema
BRVO Hemorrhages limited to one quadrant or sector of retina
Systemic Ocular
Hypertension Glaucoma
Diabetes mellitus Optic disc crowding
Atherosclerosis Increased IOP
Rheumatic heart disease Retinal vascular anomalies
Hypercoagulable states —
Condition Visual Field
CRAO Total field loss
BRAO Quadrantic or sectoral loss (e.g., superior field loss = inferior retinal BRAO)
CRVO Diffuse loss or central blurring
BRVO Sectoral field defect

Condition Management
CRAO Ocular massage, reduce IOP, hyperbaric O2, treat cause (e.g., embolus)
BRAO Often irreversible; investigate embolic source (heart, carotid)
CRVO/BRVO Control risk factors, anti-VEGF injections, grid laser (for macular edema), PRP (for neovascularization)

questions.text: All of the following are growth-promoting proto-oncogenes, except?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - TGF-β

Growth Factor

Sources

Functions

Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) including acidic (FGF-1) and basic (FGF-2)

Macrophages, mast cells, endothelial cells, many other cell types

Attracts and stimulates fibroblasts; promotes angiogenesis and ECM protein synthesis

Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)

Platelets, macrophages, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, keratinocytes

Attracts neutrophils, macrophages, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells; activates and stimulates fibroblast and endothelial cell proliferation; stimulates extracellular matrix (ECM) protein synthesis

Transforming growth factor-α (TGF-α)

Activated macrophages, keratinocytes, many other cells

Stimulates proliferation of hepatocytes and various epithelial cells

Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β)

Platelets, T lymphocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, epithelial cells, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts

Attracts leukocytes and fibroblasts; stimulates ECM protein synthesis; suppresses acute inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following fluid solutions is preferred as the maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?

questions.text: Which among the following anti-leprosy drugs can cause skin hyperpigmentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - C

questions.text: Which among the following is an HER-1 inhibitor?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Panitumu

questions.text: Identify the Pcsk9 inhibitor.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Evolocu

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics is matched correctly with its primary site of action? 1) Osmotic diuretics - Distal convoluted tubule. 2) Thiazide diuretics - Proximal convoluted tubule 3) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal convoluted tubule 4) Potassium-sparing diuretics - Collecting duct.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 3 and 4

Osmotic diuretics

Proximal convoluted tubule and descending limb of the loop of Henle

Thiazide diuretics

Distal convoluted tubule

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Proximal convoluted tubule

Potassium-sparing diuretics

Collecting duct

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects prevents the use of Teriparatide in a patient with Paget’s disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - O

questions.text: Which among the following anticoagulants requires aPTT monitoring?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Lepiru

questions.text: Sugammadex is used as a reversal agent for which of the following NMDA?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Rocuroniu

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient, after stopping the intake of alcohol, developed whole-body tremors along with vomiting and visual and auditory hallucinations. Which among the following is used to prevent another episode of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Ch

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause unexplained diarrhea?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - M

questions.text: Which anti-diabetic drugs are approved for treatment in heart failure?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - SGLT2 inh

questions.text: Which of the following is false about voriconazole?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be taken on an empty stomach

options.label: C
options.text: It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide

questions.correct_answer: C. It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - It should not be co-administered with

questions.text: Which of the following acts by suicide inhibition? 1) Spironolactone 2) Ethinyl estradiol 3) Benzbromarone 4) Ritonavir
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - 3 and 4

questions.text: A patient presents with a cough and thick sputum. What should be the drug given to this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Bromh

questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes has shown microalbuminuria in two separate urine analyses six months apart, with normal renal function test results. Which of the following is not useful in preventing renal damage progression?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Hydrochloroth

questions.text: A G2P1 delivered a preterm baby at 36 weeks. The baby was admitted to the NICU and given expressed breast milk. Unfortunately, the baby did not survive. What is used to reduce pain and engorgement of the lactating breast in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Caberg

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases the risk of UTI?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Empag

questions.text: Which drug is preferred for a 55-year-old with 150/100mm Hg BP and HbA1c 7.8%?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Liraglu

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age

questions.correct_answer: A. More commonly seen in females
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - M

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with anaphylaxis; which of the following not a part of the clinical criteria to diagnose anaphylaxis? Urticaria, edema of the lips and tongue, and rashes within 2 minutes to 2 hours of contact. Wheeze and respiratory distress Abdominal cramps and vomiting Hypertension
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - 3 and 4

questions.text: In a 70-year-old female who presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture, what is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Intramedullary
